src_text: Технологик детерминизм - ул практикалағы бик киң спектрҙар даирәһен үҙ эсенә алған, кеше яҙмышы технологик этәргестән йәки императивтан алып фәнни закондар һәм уларҙың технологияла сағылышына нигеҙләнгән логикаға ҡоролған термин.
ref_text: Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, from technology-push or the technological imperative to a strict sense that human destiny is driven by an underlying logic associated with scientific laws and their manifestation in technology.
hyp_text: Technological determinism is a term used to describe a wide range of theories that tend to explain the development of human society in terms of the development of technology. The term is also used to describe the belief that the development of technology is inevitable and that it has a single, predictable course. Technological determinism is an idea that has been around for a long time, but it has become more prominent in recent years as technology has become increasingly important in our lives. There are a number of different theories of technological determinism, but they all share the belief that technology is the primary driver of social change. One of the most famous proponents of technological determinism was the American historian and philosopher Lewis Mumford. In his book Technics and Civilization, Mumford argued that the development of technology was the primary force that shaped human history. He believed that technology was a "prime mover" that determined the course of human development. Mumford's ideas were very influential, and his work helped to popularize the idea of technological determinism. Other theorists of technological determinism include the French philosopher Jacques Ellul and the American sociologist Daniel Bell. Ellul argued that technology was the "prime mover" of history, while Bell believed that technology was the "engine of social change." Technological determinism is a controversial idea, and there are many people who disagree with it. Some argue that it is too simplistic and that it ignores the role of other factors, such as economics and politics, in shaping society. Others argue that it is too deterministic and that it ignores the role of human agency in shaping the development of technology. Despite these criticisms, technological determinism remains a popular idea, and it continues to be debated by scholars and thinkers around the world.
